comments.commentBody:
Women of Steel By JULIA BAIRD

I'm not amused informed or entertained by this unpleasant right wing Ann Randian screed. How it ever came to be in the Times escapes me. Would it not have been more appropriately placed in a propagandizing primer for aspiring young fascist?
Comparing oneself to famous people from the past is a sure way to look like a fool. Bachmann's inability to assess how others perceive her will likely be her hallmark. As for Thatcher she may be BAIRD's hero but she is in a minority and she can save the mythology for another fifty years. We saw what she did for the working people of Great Briton and we are not applauding. She was a ruthless ideologue and Bachmann has a titanium brain and never the twain shall meet, what a twinning. Regarding the film, consider that maybe you just didn't get it.
Slide # 3 is perfectly composed. Thank you Lens and Evan Vucci for this image.

He is by far the best, the most intelligent, most versatile in experience of all the Republican candidates. This country could only benefit from his experience and outlook in uniting parties instead of bickering on irrelevant or self serving issues. He gets my vote!
The real mandarin was less impressive than his Saturday Night Live sendup, where the candidate slowly turned into a lunch-counter waiter:  "Maybe little bit Chinese culture?  You pay now!"

On John Huntsman's "fluency" in Chinese, see Slate:
http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2011/10/is_jon_hu
ntsman_fluent_in_chinese_.html

Huntsman will never win the Republican nomination:
1) Huntsman is bilingual and most Republicans are English-only and they think that being bilingual hurts our country, and
2) Huntsman served his country as an ambassador...and most Republicans only serve themselves...to other people's money.
Huntsman's ads, seen by viewers in Massachusetts, are awful. And the claim by Romney that he is the soul of America suggests only that America has no soul at all. Obama 2012.

The situation is pretty clear.  We have a 4 to 1 trade deficit with China. Our persistent unemployment is largely due to the corporate export of our jobs overseas. When a patriot buys a Made-in-China product, he or she is financing the PLA. So, why does Japan get it right.  Their trade with China is approximately at parity.  Why isn't ours, Mr. Huntsman? "Merchants have no country. The mere spot they stand on does not constitute so strong an attachment as that from which they draw their gains." - Thomas Jefferson
If the GOP has any brain, it would pick Huntsman as their candidate.

I firmlybbelieve, as I have previously stated in other comments. the voters in the republican caucas are missing the opportunity to listen to John Huntsman. He was a two term governor for the state of utah and a[ppointed ambasador to China by president Obama. He is a precise and articulate speaker. If you are listening you will forget the color of his socks and tie and hear what he has to say on any number of  critical and important issues facing the American people.

Jon Huntsman will finish in the top three in New Hampshire (slightly edging out Rick Santorum for the third-spot), but has absolutely no chance of winning the Republican Nomination, and also has no possibility of being the Vice Presidential Nominee as the GOP can't have two Mormon's on the same ticket. I see him as Obama's next Secretary of State.

Huntsman, in my opinion, is the right man for the job. His experience in foreign policy (coupled with his ability to speak Mandarin) make him the man we need in office to strengthen our relations with the rest of the world and develop a foreign policy that is less militarily aggressive and more diplomatic. The world needs to work together moving forward, and the view of America needs to be that of a leader, not a policeman. Check out the details of why I want Huntsman to win this nomination here: http://wp.me/pZbhk-2k

It's great to have a President and president-candidates who have had international experience.  That worldly experience is really quite necessary in a modern world.  Not just as President, but as any sort of professional.

I read this article that claimed Huntsman's Mandarin was actually quite cringe-worthy to real fluent speakers:
http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/2011/10/is_jon...

As Ron Suskind's "Confidence Men" makes clear, staff changes have been in the works for some time. Yet Mr. Obama gives no indication of searching for a new policy orientation. Geithner remains, as one example of the president's consistent support for the business community. And this past week (although the Washington Post's coverage was more thorough than The Times) Mr. Obama's Pentagon press conference, literally surrounded by military brass, strongly suggests a still closer tie to the military and goals of global hegemony than even before.

Hence, Mr. Daley's departure means nothing in the broader picture: a failed presidency, asmeasured by the promises made during the 2008 campaign. No budging whatever on doing anything to shore up the social safety net, whether through job creation or preventing further foreclosures; nothing whatever to protect the environment or prevent climate change; nothing times nothing for the advancement of civil liberties, as Mr. Obama's DOJ consistently fights against habeas corpus rights and invokes the Espionage Act to silence and prosecute whistleblowers.

Perhaps Mr. Daley smelled a dead fish; even if Mr. Obama wins, the American people lose. He is lucky to be out the door.

I figure it must be very frustrating for Republicans watching the Clown Show going on in their primaries. Not much good news to latch onto. Well, at least here is a few likely crumbs to try to make the worse out of, right?

Please reveal these "some people". To my humble observation Barack Obama was elected by the the voters after a grueling campaign. That is how "they got there" . "Shadow President"? " A plausible explanation"?
Not really.
Really ?? Jared = Cheney ???

Obama key staff have been leaving his administration faster than you can say Mitt Romney, Newt Gingrich, Rick Santorum, Ron Paul and Jon Huntsman. While the nation has great concern about unemployment, these fellows' goal number one is to increase unemployment by one more person this November, that man in the White House who promised to keep unemployment under 8%, but for most of his tenure has seen unemployment between 8.5% and 10%.

Given that, maybe it makes sense to have his budget director become chief of staff. On the other hand, given the failure of his economic advisers to help the President drive down unemployment, maybe it doesn't make sense.

The nutcase commenters who otherwise normally reside in the comments section of the Wall Street Journal are alive and well in commentary here.

Does any of these idiots ever consider taking some time to understand and know facts about any issue rather than continually write such nonsense?

Is that like, "We're not in Kansas anymore"? Some want to know what country the President was born in. Many of us just want to know what planet he is from. The likeness to Spock is most curious. Thanks for bringing this up. It will be Duck Soup from now until November. We're on to him.
Yeah, and Chicago is probably thankful!
Mr. Obama is not in Chicago anymore.
Dr. G...That is not the case.  The Republicans most certainly did not say that.
Wow...I've always suspected that.  I guess we won't know for certain until someone with guts writes a book.
Looks like "reaching out to business" won't be part of Obama's campaign.
How does one get to be a White House intern?
